page.title: 14St. Levan Parish Church (1)
page.content: The name St. Levan comes from St. Selevan, believed to be a Celtic Saint who landed at Porth Selevan, now known as Porth Chapel, the cove lying a few hundred yards from the Church. From the{Norman Conquest until 1864}it was a chapelry of the{Deanery of St. {Buryan.}It now forms part of a united benefice with St. Buryan. Until 1832, the Church and Churchyard formed part of a small hamlet which included an Inn, which may have stood on church property.{The Holy Well and Bapistry of St. Levan lie{beside the footpath leading from the road{to Porth Chapel Beach. They are connected to the small Chapel on the cliff edge further down by a flight of about fifty stone steps. Water from the Holy Well was used for Baptisms, and is still used on occasion at the present day.
